UPDATED: DEC 17, 2007 Cork (which pops out as soon as I take off the cage) says 2004.  Poured into a tulip.  Extreme head of 4 inches from very careful pour.  Floral grass and hay notes. Nice gold color - head very gradually dissipating.  Very full with sour apple, pepper and hops.  Dry alcohol with a burn in the finish.

This pours a strong golden color with a light haze and a large, bubbly head.  The nose is sugary and the first taste is lightly citric and strongly grainy.  This imbalance is representative of many Belgian malt brews.  The light spice saves this beer from fading into obscurity.  The hops, however, are nonexistant.

on tap at the moan and dove as part of their belgian beer fest.  glad i finally got to try this amazing saison. poured golden  into a nice tulip, with a nice three finger white head. aroma and flavor of citrus, yeast, alcohol, and a nice hop balance. very enjoyable. will definitely by a bottle now.

UPDATED: FEB 13, 2008 Thanks to R.J. for this rec. Very nice light Belgian style. As others note, golden, fruity. Just a wonderful beer. Supposedly, not many made their way into our store here, but I need to grab another bottle soon before others do.

Avec les Bons Voeux pours to a beautiful, hazy, deep golden color with a thick, creamy, pillowy, white head, and a vibrant carbonation. The nose on this beer is very complex, with big aromas of pale malt, spicy/herbal hops, and peppery alcohol. The palate is richer and fuller on the tongue that Dupont, and has a very silky and smooth pale malty palate. This rich malt is paired with some nice estery fruit flavors, and some lift of carbonation that allows it to dance on the tongue. Avec les Bon Voeux finishes with more pale malt and fruit up front, then ends with a dry/spicy/peppery warming finish, that lingers on the tongue. 

This is a very delicious, very satisfying beer, that could be matched with a hearty winter dish, such as beef stew, roasted turkey, or leg of lamb. It also makes a perfect beer to relax with, as a digestif, after a big meal. This really is a big(9.5% abv), brawny version of Saison Dupont, and is one that will have you wanting much more than the 750ml bottle it comes in.
Bottled. Hazy yellow colour, small foamy head. Fruit (peaches), alcohol and weak barnyard in aroma. Also some hoppy notes, Flavour is yeast, fruits with hints of hops. Also some grassy/hayish notes.

Bottled 75cl (BBE 09/2010)
Pale yellow, a bit hazy color. Good big white cloudy head. Fruity aroma of apricot and peach, some alcohol and grassy notes too. Grassy with strong presence of yeast. Yeast in the bottom of the bottle, makes palate tastier and fruity.

Draught @ Monks.  Gld-light brown saison-looking.  Nice, generous eggshell head.  Aroma of belgian sugar, coriander, peel.  Spicy-sour-coriander/orange dry flavor.  a very light sweetness is hidden in there too.  hint of dried apricot?

(750ml bottle) Traded with Boutip. Wow... this is a good beer - even after the Fantome Pissenlit! The cork nearly killed me. The foamy white head nearly drowned me. The Stonehenge size sediment has dwarfed me. All while the flavours of orange zest, coriander, crazy farmhouse yeast with a subdivison of malt have sent me to the crazy house. This is a fine, fine beer! I look forward to going nuts on it again...
[bottle from beers of europe rating #400] The aroma is yeasty, fruity: peach banana, herbal notes of coriander. fullbodied, dry peppery finish, slightly bitter.

Hazy gold. Billowing, creamy, off white head. Aroma of big slightly sour yeast, crisp citrus/pine hops, and grains. Flavor is must, yeast, crisp hops, grains, slightly sour, moderately bitter, underlying alcohol throughout. Dry, bitter finish. Intense brew for a saison. Balanced, medium body. Excellent. Best saison Ive had.

Had this at BJs Winter Ale Fest. Beer poured a muddy dark yellow color with a large, frothy, off-white, mostly diminishing head that left behind a pretty curtain of Belgian lace. The aroma was sunny, dry and spicy: light malty notes of toasted grain, moderate hop notes of resin/pine, dry straw; heavy, nice yeasty notes of barnyard, horseblanket and basement. The flavor was moderately sweet and moderately bitter with an average-length, lightly bitter finish. The flavor was remarkable in that the initial balance was extremely on, but the individual sensations were quite discernablelike hearing a tone in either ear. The body was light-to-medium, the texture was watery, the carbonation was fizzy and the was a light alcoholic twinkle at the end. A pretty beer that seems to carry a strong sense of place with it. Neat-o.

Draft at Monks Cafe, Philly.

Aroma has a nose tickling spiciness that hints at citrus rind and sour sauce. Amber with yellow tints and a nice fluffy white head. Very yeasty fore, mild sourness and a ton of floral notes that are both spicy and sweet. Another fun drinking Saison.

75 cl bottle. Cloudy yellow colour with a large fluffy head. Aroma of tropical fruit, yeast and some sweet sourness. Flavour of yeast, malt, wheat, fruit, some sourness and very noteable alcohol, but still fresh because of the high carbonation and very drinkable.

On tap at the Hop Leaf in Chicago.  Nice White head and lacing.  Spicy aroma with a little bite on the tongue at first sip.  Yellow color that I expected.  I liked that the body did not have a thin mouthfeel.  For the amount of alcohol and the fact that it was a saison, I was impressed with the overall balance.  Very enjoyable.

Bottle. Hazy golden-amber beer with a huge whitish head. Citrus and spice in the aroma. Spicey, earthy, citrus (lemon) flavor with a bit too much residual sweetness. Some banana and alcohol that take away fromt he enjoyment. Normally a style I like, but this one just didnt hold up.
750 ml bottle, bought at Greens on Ponce in Atlanta, GA.  Pours cloudy yellow with thick creamy head.  Pleasant throughout.

On draught @ WIldeman, Amsterdam.
Hazy ochre-yellow coloured beer with a nice white head. Not very powerful aroma of yoghurt, spices and citrusfruits. Taste is spicey, gives impressions of sugar without being very sweet, and notes of vanilla and citrusfruits. Strange but satisfying brew.

This blonde ale poured with a generous white head, eliciting a musty yeast aroma. The flavor is spicy and fruity, with a carbonated mouthfeel and a smooth slightly bitter finish. Similar to, but much more complex and balanced than the Dupont Saison.
Wild yeasty and oh so good. The nose is like being on the farm. Lots of horse blanket. The palate is yeasty and full in carbonation. Very good.

Pours a very cloudy yellow with a huge frothy mirungue head. Aromas abound with sage chamomille and corriander as well as some mild horsey funk. The body is lush and CO2 filling. The flavors are a beautiful melding of spices, yeasty esters (cloves and bananas), crisp spicy hops, peppermint (yeah wierd, I know) and finishes really dry and beautifully bitter. This is quite simply a masterfully crafted beer and the finest "Super-Saison" I have had. Well worth the $$$ I paid.

Tap at Barley Johns.  Gold color with a large head.  Aroma of wheat and stale bananas.  The taste was absolutely bone dry candi sugar, if thats possible.  Slightly bitter finish.  I found it highly drinkable, but lacking any depth of flavor that warrents its reputation.

UPDATED: FEB 15, 2011 I have not been a big fan of the Dupont beers that I have tried. Sampled on draft at Zenos in State College PA this beer poured a very cloudy tan color with a medium sized white head. The aroma is light with banana and bubblegum elements. The flavor starts sweet and fruity with a bit of an alcohol burn and has a tangy fruity finish that turns a bit dry towards the end.

750 mL, snifter.  Murky amber-orange hue with a tall, rocky, meringue white head.  Musky and slightly funky aroma embraces, backlit by a soft floral warmth. Sweet notes of sugared apples.  A crisp tone not much unlike freshly pressed linen.  Fresh bananas liven the occasion.  A dry spice, nutmeg perhaps--and finished by the earthy aroma of a wet, deciduous forest.  Flavor is a sublime translation from the aroma; sweet flavors coming up front and a drying, bitter, spicy and funky finish.  Medium-full body with a soft texture and lively carbonation.

Hazy golden yellow tinged with pink when viewed from the right angle (not a right angle). A wrinkled, pillowy duvet of suds stretches over the top. Lots of pils malt in the aroma, very doughy, light evergreen and coridnader/black pepper spiciness. Flavor is lightly doughy and more pepper. Heavy spiciness with some light banana liqueur. High carbonation and a "hot" bitterness make for tingly finish.

Cold.  Hazy mellon color with a nice big white creamy head.  Big spicy aroma even when cold.  Palate is harsh on the mouth while cold, but easier as it warms.  Scrapingly dry.  Mild fruity/wheaty flavor.  Nice stuff.

UPDATED: NOV 29, 2005 Tan colored, slightly fruity, high effervescence, slight yet pleasantly bitter aftertaste, and overall well balanced. It smells similar to pilsner urquell, and in taste has a few similarities, but is far superior. It definitely needs appropriate glassware. I lowered my rating a bit after having a second bottle, which I thought unbalanced in its bitterness. Make sure you dont let this sit too long--it goes flat quick.

Bottled. Murky, pale yellow color with a GIANT white head that looks much like stiffly beaten egg whites even after 5 minutes in the glass.  Yeasty aromas of banana and apples.  Spicy taste with notes of lemon grass, apples, bananas.  Dry finish with no hop bitterness.
Pours a cloudy golden yellow color with a fluffy white head.  Nice light fruity aroma.  Flavors were pears, lemons, bananas, some citrus, and spices.  Finishes a bit abruptly.  Top notch saison!

Draft at Ølbaren.
Hazy yellow coloured with a medium sized lasting white head.
Fruity aroma with notes of spices.
Fruity flavour with notes of spices and yeast.
Dry yeasty finish.

11.2 oz bottle. cap popped off with a loud pfffff, and foam started cascading over the lip of the bottle and all over the counter. Poured into a NB glass.
Hazy orangy yellow. Lots of yeast in suspension.
Aroma is fruity with banana, apple, pear some citrus and some funky cheese. a little spicyness in there too.
Flavor is banana bread, lemon, corriander.
Finish is lightly sweet lightly dry. Awesome beer

The aroma had slight citrus, bananas, and flowers.  The flavor had soury fermented fruit, bananas, citrus, and flowers.  The beer poured a yellow color w/ no head and lacing.  The mouthfeel was light and slightly carbonated w/ a nice tartness.

750 ml. bottle. Pours a nice golden with a firm white head. A bit lighter than I remembered it. Aromas of citrus fruit, white fruit and herbal hoppiness. Also some mineral notes. On the palate it is mediumbodied, highly carbonated and with firm bitterness. 
The flavour is spicy (white pepper, coriander) and hoppy.
A very good - even excellent - beer.

Yeast and sugary.  Impossible to pour with all the foam that kept pouring out, but that was nice actually.  A little frustrating, but what Im I going to do?  Bits of fine pear, lemon, hay, weed, straw.  Bunches of dough, yeast, cookie, bread flavor to chew on.  Big mouthfeel.

75cl bottle from Beers of Europe. Golden. Looks and smells like a particularly good tripel, with that Dupont funky yeast aroma. Grapefruit, pepper and coriander on the nose also. Very smooth mouthfeel with good dry bitter finish. A cracker.

UPDATED: JUN 8, 2006 Vintage 2002.  Cork practically blew off of this bottle.  Great carbonation for being 3 years old.  3/4 inch dense and creamy head of very fine bubbles.  Amazing carbonation keep the head on the surface for the duration.  The lacing that this brews leaves is more like a quilt than a thin sheet.  Fruity aroma with lemons, yeast and grass.  An initial bit of skunkyness but that passes as the brew gets a chance to breath.  Bright gold in color with good clarity.  Light and crisp flavor with more fruityness, some spices (pepper), a nice alcohol warming and a big helping of green sour apples.  Finish has a little alcohol kick that goes right to the head.  Clean finish that is crisp and zippy. A fantastic saison and one that has aged great!

UPDATED: APR 19, 2006 (on 75cl bottle)Under "saison" there will be a picture of this, aroma of dirty horse, earth, hay and spinderweb; i know cause I come from the country side. Big white head, golden, hazy colour. Actually not much of a flavour, the finish takes over at once, with medium bitter sourness and a warming alcoholic feel - a good session beer, but a bit strong alcoholic-wise.

UPDATED: NOV 6, 2007 On tap into Duvel tulip, somewhere in the LA area.  Hazy pale yellow with a thick fizzy foam head thats large.  Glittering, uniform and sticky lacing, ok racing.  Smells like yeast, cobwebs, lemon zest and spruce.  Tastes like cloves, lemons, limes, and yeast with corriander in the finish.  Kind of watery, and I would have liked a bit more carbonation.  Better than average, but not better than that, in my opinion.

1998 Vintage!!!
When I first poured the bottle it was a strw yellow with a teeny tiny bubbeled froathy white head, and a bazillion bubbles climbing the walls of my glass. When I finally got the rest into my glass, I got all the yeast. Not sure if that is a good or bad thing. It has the horsey Belgian smell, with some Granny Smith apples thrown in for good measure. The taste is great. Pepper and apples and doughy yeast goodness. The after taste has a light lingering alcohol thing going on that works well. I would drink this everyday if I werent buzzing so hard now!!!

Simple sample still superb. Fine & funky, fruity and, and and Okay enough alliteration or whatever. That this stood out in a tasting of other equally fine beers is definitely something of a testament. Or maybe I just liked the label.

UPDATED: JAN 19, 2011 Draught at The Blue Monk, Buffalo, NY. Pours a cloudy orange with an average size diminishing white head. Very nice aroma of Belgian yeast and fruit foremost followed by light hops and spices. Flavours the same, and just as nice, of Belgian yeast and fruit along with spices and a dry bitter finish. An exceptional beer.
Original rating: 7.4.5.4.13: 3.3
Bottle shared with GregClow, tupalev & jerc -- courtesy of tupalev. Pours a dark murky yellow with a big white head. Lots of carbonation. Aroma of citrus, yeast, hay  and spices. The taste is wheaty, floral and mildly spicy. This is a typical Belgian in my opinion, its good but not really my thing.

750 mL bottle, corked & caged (2002 labeled cork, sampled June 2005): clearing golden pineapple with a mostly full and slightly diminishing starchy white, tight bubbled foam.  Tingly esters filled with honeycomb, rose petals, sweet pale malts, and slightly sour golden raisins.  There is a light astringency from the hops, but its evened out by creamy green apple sweetness and vanilla yeast complexity.  Fluffy and moist doughnut finish  spicy yeast and creamy, vanilla icing.  Not quite as dry as I was expecting in the finish which works phenomenally well with the subtle fruitiness and the yeasty ester.  Extraordinarily tasty.  Wow.

Bottle shared with blankboy, tupalev & jerc - courtesy of tupalev. Hazy golden colour with a big, foamy head. Aroma of yeast, coriander, and a faint hint of barnyard. Flavour is very nice and refreshing - citrus, coriander, clove, and a great bit of peppery heat in the back of the throat. The finish is dry and nicely hopped as well, moreso than you might expect from a Belgian. Really great, its got me jonesing for the regular Saison Dupont that will be hitting the stores in Ontario soon...

Bottle, courtesy of Boutip (thanks!).  Lat beer of the night in a decent 21 beer tasting.  Highly pressurized cork (the beer or Canada Post?).  Hazy yellow, big fizzy white head.  Subtle coriander aroma.  Strong almost wheat like taste - citrusy malts and spices abound.  Well carbonated.  Really nice and refreshing.  Subtle, yet present alcohol.  This one is a winner and a great choice to end the night with.

Okay first, I got a nailed in the forehead with the cork, thank goodness it didnt hit my eye. 750ml bottle via Mullman, thanks! Pours a slightly hazed glden hue witha huge foamy head and oustanding lace. The aroma has notes of apricot, tangerine, hayfield, dusty musty cellar esters, coriander and pepper, and a woody character. The taste starts quite floral and even a touch hoppy. I get a lot of yeast background from this beer and a nice dose of oak. The finish has a wonderful spicy note and the citric nature comes rushing forth. The feel is quite lively and very refreshing, almost too much as I had finish most of the bottle before I knew it. This is a world-class brew, no question about it. Gosh how I fell into the magic that is a great saison. Very much recommended!

UPDATED: MAY 26, 2005 Thanks a lot hey_kevin. Pours a light gold with a huge white head. The aroma is hay with some butterscotch and oak. There is also some of that subtle oraganic barnyard. The taste is hay with grass and fresh chocolate. There is also a subtle spice of corriander. Plenty of carbonation. Absolutely wonderful beer.
this is just wonderfull. aroma has a full palate of citrus spices honey and yeast. fruity spicey taste. finish is also  hmmm...  retronasal . its just a wonderful life.

UPDATED: JAN 5, 2009 On tap @ hopleaf. Cloudly yellow with a white head. Citrusy, yeasty, spicy aroma. Taste is lemon citrus, vanilla, yeasty, with some spice and some bitterness towards the finish. The difference is negligible between this and the Dupont Saison. This one is twice as alcoholic? 3.9 overall   750ml bottle, served at basement temperature of 55°. Just wonderful. 4.1 overall.

Tap at Hop Leaf, 2005:  Hazy blond pour, fluffy head.  Aromas of candi sugar, grassy hops, and yeast.  Much sweeter on the tounge than the nose woudl initially have you believe.  Sweet with intresting spice and yeasty notes.  Intresting, but a bit too sweet for me.

2002 750 ml bottle. Pours light tangerine with a lasting fluffy head. Nice tart, earthy aromas abound. Taste is crisp and refreshing with pepper, earth, leather and tart. Smooth and light, this stuff masks the 9.5% real well. Addictive.

750 ml bottle, greedily drunk all alone...near-white whipped-cream tops a translucent, pale gold and shiny body...gorgeous mix of vanilla and sharp herbs (tarragon, rosemary, coriander), lemon-orange and a bit of oak...luscious, full mouthfeel, herbal pungency mixes exquisitely with the sweet vanilla-orange Creamsicle dessert...alcohol only vaguely present at the back end, and its muted and warming...a liqueur-like saison for the few cold nights left to us, or to bring in Spring like a true lion!

The beer disembarks the 750ml cork and caged green bottle a shining gold with a prodigious creamy bright white head that lingers for quite sometime, and the lace forms a thick and clinging blanket upon the glass. Nose has a tangy spiciness, over ripe fruit, seemed to be a mix of bananas and pineapples, crisp and clean, hints of clove also noticed, maybe even a bit of fusel alcohol, a complex one at any rate, start is sweet and the grain profile noticeable, the top is light to moderate in feel. Finish is caustic, hops are pleasantly spicy, vinous, devastatingly dry and the aftertaste welds itself to your palate, and the 9.5 percent ABV warmed my tummy noticeably, a great beer for a Sunday afternoon.

4/17/05: Bottle, 2004 vintage Thick , rocky head which clings to the glass, leaving an XL amount of lace.  Golden sunshine body with chunks.  Aroma of cheese, fruit, clove and yeast.  Flavors of cheese, yeast and slightly spicy.  Dry finish.

2002 bottle.  hazy yellow gold color, nice fluffy white head with medium last.  yeasty/musty/funky aroma.  slightly cheesy and tangy too.  very high caronation, dryish and very fruity/tangy flavor.  kind of dry aftertaste.  thanks jimmack04!
This is a good Saison.  Some what tart, herb, and earthy flavor. Finishes clean, crisp, and dry.  Thanks Jimmack04.

Pours a hazy golden color with a thick white head that is well retained.  Aroma is somewhat similar to a Flemish Sour, but less sour and more spicy, with some orange zest and yeastiness.  Flavor is fruity and a bit sour, but as it warms the alcohol emerges.  Some apple, honey, banana and pepper flavors.  I keep a couple of bottles cellared for holiday meals.

Bottle: Poured a hay blonde looking beer with a huge white foamy head with great retention. Aroma is dominated by the floral yeast with some good strong malt also present. Yeast is very noticeable as you start sipping this beer and malt mix with spices also become more apparent as you drink. Funky aspect is quite present thought not as much as the Veille Saison Dupont. Still very enjoyable and alcohol is not detectable.

Hazy golden colour with huge white head. Strong aroma, spicey, citrus and alcohol. Taste is has tastes of fruits, yeasts, spices and alcohol. Bitter but crisp, a nice drink overall and makes you want more.

Nice hazy golden color with warm glow and with big lively white head. Fine refreshing aromas with hints of yeast, citrus, fresh fruits, pepper, some spices, rice crackers, white bread and sesameseeds. Taste is great and complex, it has hints of fruits and touches of wet soil, also accents wet forrest. There is a nice balance between the fruity accents that brings the lively and refreshing notes in this brew, and the nutty earthy flavours who are responcible for the roundness and the body in this beer. The afthertaste is again on the dry fruity side and has a fine freshness in the end.

2002 Bottle. Hazy golden color with a large, thick white head. Aroma hit me as I was pouring. Musty, yeasty, with some citrus and spiciness. Awesome!
Flavor starts off mildly sweet, with lots of fruitiness, yeast and pepper. Finishes quite dry. Very refreshing, especially for a beer of this strength.
Bottled: Hazy golden coloured. Beige dense head. Yeast, wheat and fruit in the nose. Flavour is spiced, yeasty and has loads of fruit. Is sweet. Is nicely fruity in the end. This is a good one.
2001. Golden coloured. Fruity, yeasty aroma. Quite dusty flavour. Some yeasty bitterness in the end. Strange, but interesting.

2004 bottle: Pours a clear bright golden with a huge rocky and frothy head with lots of clumpy lacing.  Aroma is dry, soapy, and bready with lots of Belgian yeastiness.  Starts with a bready dry caramel sweetness and a touch of candi sugar toward the earthy, dry, yeasty finish.  A nice saison with decent complexity. Thanks Silphium!

This beer was sampled at the 12 Hour Belgian Beer Festival at Pizza Port 2005. This beer pours a beautiful ever so slightly cloudy golden color with a carbonation tornado right in the middle of my glass. The head is majestic and thick with massive lacing coating the glass thoroughly! The aroma is barnyardish, with heavy yeast, lemon, and a ton of spices...heavy peppers. The flavor is full bodied and complex..very tart and lemony, yet complex with sweet fruits and a touch of pepper in the finish. Excellent sweet and sour contrasts...the yeasts were super tasty and the beer awesomely fresh..perhaps a slight hint of olive oil in the finish....I enjoyed it to say the least..but oh that aroma... I could have smelled it all day.

Pours with a cloudy orange-gold body topped by a thick head with lots of lacing.  The aroma is slightly sweet and slightly spicy with nice fruity  (orange zest) notes adn a touch of yeastiness.  The flavor is slightly sweet yet slightly bitter with nice spicy notes, a touch of fruit and some yeast.  Light to medium bodied, smooth and a touch dry.

sampled at the pizza port belgian fest 2005.
hazy yellow, thick head. sweet, spicey, an excellent saison

Poured a slightly hazy yellow with a huge rocky thick longlasting head.  Aroma of yeast, dough, clove, and citrus.  Flavor is citrus and yeasty with a sweet, spicy, alcoholic finish.  Alcohol is balanced with the other flavors however.

2004 Bottle:  Beer pour expected slightly cloudy medium golden with a beautifully retained egg white head.  Then a whiff of aroma and BAM what kind of Saison is this?  Significant hoppy aroma with fruit and yeast.  Flavor is initially light fruit, also yeast and the afore mentioned hops.  Very light and dancing in the mouth.  All in all a delightful beverage.

I just tapped a keg of this rarity about two hours ago, and something struck me right off, a thing happened that is most uncommon: a beer took my breath away. 
Looks majestic poured into a St. Bernardus goblet, lush creamy head, hazy pale orange appearance, ...angelic.
Aroma, captivating, airy, light citrus, minor sour tones, vibrant fruit, apricot, peach, lemon, gets bolder by the minute, unfolds tangy-er fruit notes, ...uplifting.
But its in the taste where I was taken back, and I still dont know if I have language for it, but let us make a valiant effort, anyway.
Fruit floods the mouth, but the body is exceptionally light, almost ethereal...it paints a coating of delicious around the mouth that pulls away like a phantom, the echo of this gorgeous fruit flavor, plump with yeast, lingers, resonates, titillates, entices...another sip is in the offing, but it becomes a gulp, and the swallow is urgent, but the effect is the opposite, a magnificent restfulness overcomes me, a mellow rapture,... it stirs the mind and soul, and quenches thirst along the way.
Each new sip delivers a similar shock, a brand new spank to the senses, a reacquaintance with this magical feeling.
Body is light, but the flavor is powerful and pure, and the finish is long, fruity, perfectly smooth. I laugh at the 9.5% but feel it creeping in as I drain the glass.
Hey, maybe its just the mood Im in, but this glass of beer has an absolutely elevating effect. The strength eventually enters into the flavor like a wily snake through a grassy field....lightly spicy, too, to match the fruit...call me a sucker if you must, but I feel my soul has been cracked open, freed and sent aloft, metamorphosized, like hearing new beautiful music for the first time, have a soft spot touched and felt that shiver...
Amazing beer. Not good, not great, amazing! Utterly lovely.
A great gift from Dupont. Thank you, thank you, thank you!

Dusty, almost opaque blonde, with a decent thick white head and lots of flaky sediment.  Aroma has just a good balance of sweet and funk, lemon-lime, candi sugar, and a little resinous.  Good acidity and lively carbonation, yeasty and bready with some undisclosed spicy cereal taste.  Very satisfying.
A nice saison with lots of spice and a good hops character in the aftertaste.  Nice color and enormous head.  I didnt like this as much as the other saison from Dupont, but still very nice.

UPDATED: OCT 9, 2007 Fresh cut hay, overripe melon, citrus-lemon-lime and some lightly spicy, grassy hops in the nose.  Opaque tan-yellow with generous and lasting white head that recedes slowly with some lacing.  Plenty of yeast in suspension.  Generally spicy flavour has all the notes of the aroma with a strong herbal/spicy character.  Medium-light body with refreshing strong effervescence.  Bottle sampled at the Voyager par des Papilles group tasting Feb-05.

Its not bad even though saisons dont do it for me at all. Thanks be to edward (brooklynboy) for the cool find. Very acidic taste and lots of yeast. It is strong but barely drinkable. Im sure that if I wanted to tough this one out I would be able to take it.

Pours a hazy blonde color with yeast sediment and a thin white head. Excellent aroma and flavor of spices, citrus, resin and yeast. Light to medium body, creamy texture, medium carbonation. Hmmm, excellent !

Bottle courtesy of Matta. Pours dirty golden yellow with just a ring of bubbles. Very sour like skunk aroma, oddly not a bad skunk aroma. Little too carbonated. Flavor is strange yeast with a nice sourness to it. Also has a stramge sweetness about it. Very complex brew, I would probably rate higher to style. But overall very good anyway.

Just didnt do it for me.  Very few saisons do.  Light amber with a champagne-like head.  The aroma was spicy, yeasty, cidery, fruity.  Medium body, smooth mouthfeel, lively carbonation.  Flavor was spicy, acrid, funky, unpleasant.  No thanks.

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2008 Minimal aroma, and only lightly carbonated with very little head. Aroma is slightly citrusy with a metallic cidery note. Taste is same, and finishes dry with some fruityness and a slight tannic presence.  Perhaps this was from a faulty batch, but this product did not meet my expectations, although it improved my perception of its type.
This is a wonderful beer.  It has a lovely light amber color, a nice amount of carbonation, a flowery nose and a taste of honey.

UPDATED: FEB 12, 2005 Great spicy and estery aroma, although the appearance was lacking.  Slight head and slight carbonation for a saison, but very fruity and estery.  Still very refreshing despite its strength.   Great aftertaste and smooth finish.
Draught. Sour wheat aroma. Cloudy yellow colour. Wheaty, yeasty flavour.

Aroma:Fruity and spicy.   
Appearance:gold good head.  
Flavor:Spicy,malt.citrus and small bitterness.

Exquisite Savoir-Faire!
Hazy golden in color with a thick creamy head that last forever. The nose is bready, like sourdough (this is the yeast)
and somewhat like pastry or Marzipan.
Highly carbonated.
Medium to full body, crisp and clean, it 
goes down amazingly well despite 9,5%.
A pure beauty of a beer.

Bottle from Styles via Matta!!!!  Thanks guys.  WIld funky aroma of Brett. and farm.  Something about this smell gets me going now.  Hazy yellow color with a nice white head.  Good lacing.  Light  body.  Very carbonated, like vinegar and baking soda.  Funky citric acid flavors.   Nice!!
Draught. Hazy orange color with a big white head. Spicy herbal lemon aroma and a sweet malty herbal taste. Medium to full body and a long sweet dry finish.
Hazy orange colour with white head. Nice fresh herbal aroma. Malty flavor with hints of flowers, hoppy bitter finish.
Bottle. Cloudy orangy golden color with thick white head.  Aroma is grassy and herbal.  Floral, herbal taste with some spice.  Very, very smooth.  Almost silky.  Excellent beer.

2004 cork date, Sampled January 2005
As I pour this beer into my glass I get an aroma that is enticingly sharp, grassy and herbal all together.  The beer is a lightly hazy straw gold color, it is topped by a frothy, rocky off pale white head.  Ooh, the aroma is quite nice it has aromatic notes of bergamot, fresh cut hay, wild flowers, lemon zest, vanilla, and perhaps a soft woodiness.  The aroma is quite smooth and almost mellow in character, though it is quite complex and intriguing.

This beer starts out smooth but then starts to pick up a sharpness in the middle, but then finishes with a lingering malty smoothness.  This beer is quite tasty, it does not have the complexity of the Saison Dupont, but it is still quite tasty and much more mellow and smooth tasting.  The flavors that meld together in this beer are quite nice, I get notes of lemon, pepper, ginger, a tannic woodiness, and some sharp herbal notes.  This beer has a really nice flowery, almost nectar like, quality to it that is just so smooth and satisfying.  It really hides its alcohol quite well.  This beer is quite tasty and is really growing on me more and more as I drink it.

In the end this is just a wonderful mix of flavors, textures and aromas.  This beer is quite good, and is perhaps my second favorite (after the Saison) from this incredible brewery.

It was a pleasure to try this beer on draught tonight at Toronado in San Francisco, California.  Pale yellow in color with a large head of foam.  The aroma is distinctly Dupont, subtle, fruity with hints of hay, glue and pear, lots of pear.  The aroma isnt very captivating quite honestly, but the taste, that is another story.  Dry, with big, almost sour yeasty/farmhouse notes with big fruit flavors (pear, apple), caramel and this is awfully hoppy by the way.  A very good beer.  But this is far from being as magical as the 8% Blaugies beers and some of the Fantome beers.

2004 bottle with many thanks to my secrent santa (JCW) for sendin it.  A tremendous pop when pulling the cork signals this is going to be well-carbonated and in need of a good deal of breathing.  After 15 or so minutes, I pour in to a tulip what looks to be a bubbly pale-gold liquid, with some light rusty tinges and persistent mountainous white head.  Lightly hazy, with a few flecks of yeast suspended.  It smells earthy, like damp hay and mold, with some rusty, lightly citric bitterness and a dry caramel nuttiness.  The flavor is full and rich, with a huge yeast apparency, persistent sweetness from the honey-almond like malt, with dry caramellized sugar notes.  Grain-like spicy notes abound throughout, with a pleasing, zesty mouthfeel and medium-full body.  Finishes dry, nutty, yeasty with plenty of honey-wheat breaddough-like flavors and more light citrus hanging around.  A good bridge between the sweeter, moldy, cheesy Pipaix and the spicy, more lean and crisp Vieille Provision, as others have noted.

Tap @ Toronado 12/31/04.  This seemed to be rare find on tap ($8.50/glass) and well worth it.  Ive never seen a bottle of it.  A rich orange and gold color with a foamy white head.  Candy, bubblegum, spiced and citrus flavors.  Smooth and creamy without the bite that I expected at the finish.  Sweet finish with a long dry aftertaste.
Tap at monks.  Slightly cloudy, orangish.  Aroma is belgian yeast in character.  Sweet at first, with a very pleasant and slightly sour aftertaste.
2003 bottle.  Slightly hazy in color, with a nice perfect white head.  Smooth citrus flavor.  Malt flavor is smooth. Very smooth and drinkable. Enjoyable. Excellent beer.

Bottle from 2003, aged 1 year. yeallow, slightly hazy, perfect white head. Mellow citrus aroma (orange or lemon peel).  Smooth light mellow malty citrus flavor. Slight orange or lemon peel bite in the finish. Sooper smooth and drinkable. Tastes non-alcoholic....
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: 12.28.04  750ml bottle.  Pours brilliant, hazy golden, highly effervescent, ridiculously massive, rocky, sticky white head.  The room is filled with wonderful citrus, pear, Belgian yeasty aromas, hints of funk, fontina, white grape.  This beer is going to be good and Im completely surprised...I really didnt know what to expect.  The first sip reveals a glorious brew that seems a cross between wheat beer, abbey tripel, and saison: its strong, for sure, so sweet and smooth, dabblings in banana, spice (corriander), lithe citrus hints that dance and play with subtle funk.  Cool driness helps to finish the brew and makes it unwittingly drinkable.  Enjoyable throughout.  Great beer.

On draft at Monks in Philadelphia

All of the traditional saison elements, adding a strong banana nut character.  Pours with huge lacing atop a cloudy golden body.  Finish is both yeasty and boldly hopped.  Warm and friendly.

Five beers for a thousand - Beer #997. Draught at Delirium Cafe, Brussels. Cloudy yellow/orange. Aroma of fruit & cheese. Flavour is sweet, very fruity and lovely. Not an off flavour in sight, this is incredibly soft and the alcohol is so well hidden. What little alcohol can be detected works so well and is so very pleasent at this massive strength. Wonderful beer.

On tap at Monks in Philly.  Wow is all I have to say.  A ton of different flavors in there, including fruity notes, sourness, bubblegum, and a bit of bitter.  Quite strong for something so refreshing.

Big grassy hoppy aroma, with a gigantic billowing head.  Crystal clear golden.  Lean, fairly light bodied.  Big clean hoppiness.  Perfect balance of body and zippy carbonation, with that goregous signature dupont yeast character.  This is a sexy beer.  Put the pen down and enjoy it!  Thanks to Matt_Dinges for a great beer shared with great company.

Draft: golden yellow, cloudy, thick white head, lacing on glass, aroma of funk, yeast, apple?, flavor is subdued, yeasty with some pepper and bread, slight citrus taste, and a mild bitter finish. Pretty good

12/19/04.  On draft at Lucky Baldwins in Pasadena, CA 12/19/04.  Hazy golden tan.  Dense, fluffy, creamy pillow of head, eggshell in color with a slight yellow tinge.  Superb lacing.  Delicious, subtle yeasty nose with pear, apple, pepper and light coriander and clove.  Slightly doughy and subtly sweet in the nose.  Initial taste is like a Belgian golden ale, slightly bitter, moderately yeasty, with a touch of pepper.  Finish has moderate dryness with slight sting of alcohol and delicious warm hum; wonderful seque from the first taste into the smooth, lasting, crisp and elegant finish.  Not too much, but definitely plenty there.  Full body.  Just wished the head lasted longer than it does.  Bitterness lasts a long time on the finish, as does the peppery coriander/yeast combo.  Lovely beer.

UPDATED: MAR 10, 2006 On tap at Monks Café. Poured a lighter, hazy yellowish color with a smaller white head. I had this one after drinking 3 darker beers (Bells Exp., Aventinus Eisbock & Le Coq Imp. Stout) - it was a nice change of pace. Aromas and tastes of lemons, fruity, and light spices. Light yeast. The body seemed a little thin (but the previous beers could have something to do with that). Ill have to revisit this one (I have a bottle sitting in the cellar).

Retried on 3/9/06. Increased some of the rating points as I really liked this the 2nd time around.

pours a orangish gold color with a nice tall foamy head, spicy aroma, lots of fruit and citrus, malty, sweet and spicy, taste has a nice initial sweetness, then changes to a sour citrus taste before leaving my palate with a decent smooth malt.

Pours a cloudy light orange with a tall rocky white head. Aroma is very yeasty, floral, light spice, with hint of orange peel and clove. Taste has a nice carbonation that really brings the flavors up front quickly. Yeasty flavors give this brew a breadiness, and the light orange peel iss very refreshing. This brew has a very dry mellow hop finish, with a hint of lemon, and a light tartness.

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2007 Pours yellowish orange.  Translucent and pours with a frothy white head.  Aroma is yeasty and of light belgian candi sugar, with light amount of spice(clove).  No alcohol in the flavor to speak of.    Bubbly.  Finish is slightly hoppy up front and sweet through out.

Bottle pours golden, large foamy white head, fantastic lacing, with very light carbonation.   Sweet & tart aroma, slightly floral.   Candied malt sweetness up front, with a very subtle tart floral flavor on the backside.   Alcohol is well hidden, but definite warming feeling.   Good body and mouthfeel.   Slight bitterness that lingers.   The sweetness and tart aspects of this brew are well balanced.   Tasty!

Pleasing golden body with a thick layer of foam on top.  The aroma is spicy, clove, pepper, and some leafy malt and yeast notes.  The flavor is only a tad bitter, but bits of peach, lemon and honey are all present.  Quite the outstanding beer.  Very complex, yet keeps a good enough presence to not be over the top.

UPDATED: DEC 22, 2004 Very good! Im liking these Belgian Saisons.  The taste of this was like citrus, wheat and malt combined.  The aroma was similar to Aventinus which of course pleases me.  The alcohol was barely noticable.  Really a wonderful beer.  I recommend it.

UPDATED: DEC 14, 2004 A work of art. Pours hazy orange with a fluffy white head. Aroma is of hay, citrus, a slight barnyard, vanilla, and a mild peppery spice. Flavor is same as the aroma but with the addition of a buttery cider and a mild banana ester. The palate is extremely creamy and smooth. The alcohol is not noticible except possibly as a warmth that makes the flavors brighter. Every time you take a sip you get a different layer of flavor. And all of the layers fit together perfectly. The best saison I have had to date.

UPDATED: JUL 29, 2006 Golden colour. Fruity aroma. Spicy, bitter, fruity taste. Yeasty and malty. 
Very nice brew. Very smooth. Be sure to let it stand for some years.

UPDATED: AUG 8, 2005 On tap at the White Horse, Parsons Green, London. Luminous goldem, with no head. Deliciously sweet, slightly creamy. Slight sour funk, which is swept away on the finish by wheaty flavour. Some cider. Warms the chest. Powerful, but easy drinking. Excellent.
bottled 750 ml. 2002 Golden orange with large white head. Sweet and Spicy. The barnyard hay yeast taste. A good Saison.

Cloudy yellow-orange body with plenty of dark sediment; frothy off-white head.  Yeasty, very peppery aroma with flower petals and lemon.  The flavor was quite spicy (peppery) with tons of light fruit, crackers, hints of apple, and flower petals.  Alcohol was apparent.  The dense lemon pepper characteristic is reminiscent of a super-sweet pilsener, as humulus suggested.

(vintage 2000) Dark hazy golden, rich fluffy white head. Herbal, yeasty, peppery and rather vinous aroma. Nice. Flavour starts of sweet honey like malts. Finishes of herbs, hay, pepper, yeast, cheese, wood, all-spice and alcohol. Soft mouthfeel. Excellent saison!

2002: Poured deep golden orange with big fluffy white head...smell is very spicy...yeast, pepper and the like...taste is quite hoppier than I expected...sweet malts at first, and only for a second...then spices: pepper, coriander, a hint of cinnamon?...finish is dry and peppery...greatness

75cl bottle Bottled in 2002.  Ill admit that I am writing some of this review after the fact. The beer was just too captivating for me to keep  taking notes.  Im not a ratings whore, Im not doing it just to get the rating.  But I figured it was time I had an absolute favorite beer.  Their Saison is pretty high up there.  But this one(hey_kevin and I discussed it as being a tripel) blows me away.  Hops.  This is a wonderful, hoppy tripel.  It isnt thick or watery.  Perfect.  Once of the finest smelling beers Ive ever had.  Alcohol is hidden bu a wonderful menage-a-trois of hops, yeast and malt.  Some nice farmyard character sneaks up too.  I cant say more.  My idea of beer perfection.

Cheers Jeff - another really good beer you shared with me. Beautifully hazy gold with plenty of frothy head. Lots of yeast and tartness in the aromas but some sweetness too. Citric and tart, it lingered with a slight mustiness and some spicy bitternes too. Interesting saison, but definitely enjoyable.

UPDATED: OCT 1, 2004 Im not quite sure when this bottle was brewed, but Im am quite sure it was utterly delicious.  Sampled with a great friend, and a few others.  A delicate, nimble brew, very aromatic.  Luscious herbal tones, estery, cork, wood, earth; sexy vibrant funk.  White pepper, spice, aged hops?  Very delicious, I enjoyed it to the last yeasty drop.  Very, very good, in my humble opinion.

Pours golden, big white head. A ton of carbonation in my bottle, the cork said 2002 on it. A lot of yeast in the aroma, with some alcohol notes and spiciness. Beautiful flavor, yeasty, spicy, and sweet, with a slight burn in the finish. Thanks to matta for this one!

Hazy gold in colour with a large white head.  Aroma was yeasty, with small amounts of alcohol, lots of orange and lemon zest, some spice.  Flavour had yeast and mustiness upfront, citrus, spices in the middle and small amount of alcohol in the end.  Finishes somewhat sharp with a lingering medium bitterness.  If I didnt know that this was going to be a saison I would have sworn that it was a triple.  A very enjoyable beer.

call it a sin, call it crazy but we drank way too many beers at this cafe in brugg, belgium and this is the last of them. how accurate the rate? your guess is as good as mine? once again this was recommended to us by a frieindly chap that we had met at the cafe and gave us a whirlwind taste of his favorite beligum brews. poured out all over into the three glasses placed on the bar... orange yellow with a big explosive tnt head. nose of fruit citrus banana spice and some leather. up into the filiform makes you think of fresh bread yeast, brown sugar babies, and bananas and spice with some citrus cutting down that pine back door that you need to replace. quite special of a beer and even more for the memory. thank you to our friend (dont know his name) in belgium, as we stumbled back to the train and slept all the way back to brussels.

Hazy gold with a frothy white head. Superb lacing. Its a beauty. Sour with some funk, bitter hops as well as floral. Pears and apricots. Spicy touches of coriander. Flavor contains a big wallop of coriander and hops. Bitter, floral and citrus. Its also quite barnyardy. Palate is a bitter bite of sour apples with a spicy finish. Great.

Hazy gold beer with a nice thick white head. Spiced up yeasty aroma with belgian style-hops. Dance of malts and hops and orange peels with bitter hops. nice lacool warmth and delightful body. Wants to stay in my mouth. Merci a MT.

Huge props to matta for sending me this beer!  Hazy gold, pretty head that lasts.  The aroma has that barnyard funk going, along with a bit of tangerine and grain.  Flavor matches, but goes through stages as it warms.  In the beginning, the finish has a dry, spicy note, almost a hop bitterness.  As it warms, more citric fruit flavors come through, along with a faint barnyard note.  Another exceptional brew from one of my absolute favorite brewers.
This is a very yeasty brew. It has some alcoholic, wheaty and metallic notes.

Bottle. Had this with some spicy hot Morrocan food, bad move i say, but the beer was still great. Full on spicy, pepper, Belgian yeasty flavour. Wheaty, bready malts, orange rind. Finish is quite peppery and bitter, quite dry too. Rich flavour, yeasty,  intersting, earthy, country style!

Big white head, amber body. And a mighty flavour. Really a super-saison for the cold winter days. Outstanding hoppy, flowery flavour masking the underlying alcohol. Dupont makes such wonderful beers, and for me this is the best (until I find a Cervasia again). In my opinion, this is the best non-lambic Belgian beer.
Golden coloured. Nice aroma of hops and flowers. The flavour is more fruity and malty.

UPDATED: NOV 25, 2007 2002 vintage: Explosive cork removal.  Faded yellow body with some haze. Climbing white head from the surging carbonation. Impeccable lacework. Luxurious aroma of buttercup, peppery hops, and perfumey esters. Perfect level of airiness and vibrant yeast complement the pale malts and sugared white grapes. Light swirls unleash sweet cream, coconut, and coarseness from the hops. Seductively creamy, dense, yet expansive, carbonation. Moderate sweetness from the start with a dessert apple, white grape, glazed malt medley. Fresh flowers soften the body and reduce the sweetness while the hallmark Dupont yeast goes to work and continually films the palate while adding some cakelike thickness. Remarkably restrained fruity esters, apple acidity, and vivacious Styrians try to expunge the alcohol, but the alcohol eventually wins and warms the belly. Leafy hops gradually strut toward the finish alongside muted mustiness and juicy hops. Fluffy, fresh cake moistness (less dry than the regular Dupont) in the finish with a balance of apple skins,  flowers, and yeast astringency. Juicy hops and sweet white grapes remain amid herbs and fading pale malts. Only flaw is the (relatively) poorly-hidden alcohol in the flavor. Earth shattering every time.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: Bright, herbal/citrus yeasty funk. Emphasis on spices: clove and coriander mingle with lemon peel sharpness. Soft, almost bready finish. Very tasty.
Poured a hazy gold color with a small white head and nice lacing,  Earthy aroma of citrus and yeast.  Spicy coriander, orange peel, yeast, and alcohol noticeable in the taste.

1500ml(!). Pale orange, cloudy. Thin white head. What an aroma: lots of sweetness, lots of citrus, yeasty with hints of spices (cinnamon and coriander). Flavor is toned down a notch, but not much. again a dominant sweetness with malts, some alcohol and acidic. A bit too sweet and too much alcoholic for my taste but else good.

A hazy orange beer with a disappearing head. The aroma is sweet malty with notes of coriander. The flavor is sweet malty. This beer is boring compared to loads of others - I think I have to resample one day.

Yes, a replacement for champagne. Even non-beer drinkers will like. Like a good French white wine, nicely carbonated, with lemon and zest and vanilla. Good combination of hops, spices. Nice white head that stays. Crisp aftertaste.

Matta is such a stellar individual  Clear liquid gold wearing a foamy, frothy, rocky gigantic-sized white head. Very carbonated body. Gotta love such a complex aroma that never hinted at being not as great as expected by me (who still recently fell under the charm of their Dupont Forêt). Ultra farmy, dry and yeasty, very yeasty obviously like all other Dupont. Lovely barny and spicy hints. How can you not love a fine Saison. Bone-dry (made me think of chalk at times) with awesome white wine aspects. Deep spice profile includes coriander, basil, pepper, thyme, mint, sage and just various other herbs. The first sip proposes a malty attack with lots of dry hay, some apple and so much yeast. Finish is dry with a grassy hop bitterness, but remains restrained and balanced. Aftertaste comes back to haunt me with suggestions of dust and spices and that scores big points with me. So herbal, so intense and no alcohol to speak of although there's a charming warming effect. Body is medium, quite carbonated, mouth-cleaning for sure and lightly tart at times. Marvellous Marvel. I'm truly impressed and in great thirst of Saison for the rest of my days. Help me!

UPDATED: APR 23, 2009 Pendulous foamy white head and slightly hazy lemon yellow body with substantial streaming carbonation. Aroma of bread, yeast, apples, citrus, toasty malts, and light esters. Organic flavor of orange citrus, wheat, hay, leather, and aspartame with medium bitterness, medium acidity, and medium sweetness. Nicely rounded with considerable depth. A great saison. My favorite.

Pours a hazy golden body with a thick foamy head. Aroma is spicy and heavy - yeast, hops, fruit, citrus and different spices. Flavor is also very full with citrus, yeast, hay, lots of spices and some alcohol. A thick mouthful and a really flavorful beer.
2 years old. Cloudy golden with nice head. Spice, yeast, non-aggressive hops. Soft palate.

2002. Cloudy orange, belian white looking beer. Nice developed head (from five or six pours. Nice high foam, lace. Smells of coriander, orange peel, bubble gum, vanilla. The taste is very tart, nice bitterness but quite acidic. Some citrus peel flavors going on as well.  Nice but the bitterness lasts for quite some time. Dry mouthfeel. This would be nice with a sweet dessert.

UPDATED: APR 18, 2004 Cork Reads 2002
 Ive had this beauty sitting for about 9 months, I couldnt resist any longer!
 King Midas touched  this beer as it poured a pale golden / orange body, with the chunkiest and most nugget like ivory head ever created. The nose is soft as cotton, light and perfumey suggestions of clove, sage, hints of coriander, and a lovely yeasty / biscuity euphoria.
  The flavor is full of character. Notes of  orange and lemon take front stage... spices like: cardamom, clove, coriander, and black peppercorns take left; and a barnyard mustiness of grains work the right. An airy  and creamy palate accompany the tart and spicy citric finish And with that.. An artisan has crafted a work of genius and contained it as liquid gold!

UPDATED: JAN 5, 2006 Off-white creamy head, good lacing and mostly lasting.  Murky, white body.  Lightly hoppy aroma (flowers, citrus).  Lighlty sweet, lighty bitter initial flavour.  Moderately bitter short finish.  Dry mouthfeel, lightly astringent.

UPDATED: JUL 8, 2011 2010-08-12, corked bottle at Ris Ras, Århus, vintage 2008, 7-5-6-3-12=33Cloudy orange-golden color; medium sized creamy head. The aroma is difficult to decribe, it has some malt and spices and Belgian yeast, but also some vegetables. The mouthfeel is weaker than expected, and a bit dry; the combination of malt and spices produces again some trait of vegetables. It has enough bitterness; in the final the alcohol is quite evident. Possibly it was stored in some hot places for some time.2006-11-27, Draught at Den Tatoverede Enke, 7-4-8-4-16=39Spicy aroma (cloves, coriander), a bit fruity (mango). Good Belgian body, dry malt, spices, lemon peel, upcoming strong bitterness. Very different, but good anyway.2004-02-21, Bottle, 5 years old, 8-5-8-4-16=41Gold color, creamy head; nice perlage. Aroma of cellar, wood, cork, old hop flowers. Very good Strong Belgial Ale, malty, that has lost some sweetness due to the long aging; strong final bitterness.

UPDATED: AUG 29, 2008 (Bottled, 0.75l) Hazy golden color with a large, white, quite tight head. Quite strong, dryish, earthy, yeasty and hoppy aroma with a hint of cardamom and thyme. Dry, hoppy, yeasty and fruity flavor with peppery spiciness and a hint of alcohol in the finish. Somewhat acidic, but gets softer and sweeter with the yeast poured in. Medium-bodied, dryish, bitter-hoppy, biting palate. A very nice, saison-like, crisp and strong ale. Maybe the strongest-hopped Dupont.

Bottle conditioned. 750ml bottle. Faintly hazy gold, good thick fluffy white head and good condition. Perfumed honey, alcoholic, yeasty and slightly spicy in the nose. Sweetly yeasty and grainy in the mouth with a floral perfume note and traces of apple . Quite dry and apple citric in the finish.
Vanilla, wheat, alcohol, citrus and spice.  Cloudy yellow in the glass, Pure white champagne head.  Yeasty wheat, tart flavor.  Pleasant body and creaminess

Golden, sparkling colour.  Yeasty, peppery aroma with pear esters.  Some Bernie Worrell understated funk appears amidst typical Dupont yeast feast.  Spicy, dry, slightly acidic.  A fun take on saison, brining Dupont and Pipaix closer together.

Cloudy pale yellow in colour with a big white head.  Aromas are citrus and yeasty.  Flavours are again citrus and yeasty with a hoppy bitterness on the finish.  Has a great foam mouthfeel. Is a great beer.
Clear golden body with a big foamy head. Lemony, grass and yeasty aroma. Soft mouthfeel. Taste has some slight citric notes and an underlying funkiness. Finishes dry and yeasty. Very nice.

(Very well seasoned sample on 75cl.) Explosive gushing to huge, but not very stable white head; fully hazy pale peach-orange beer. Barnyard and earthy aromas, leather, citruszeste, faint spices and fresh white bread with nuts in the nose. Again very earthy, leafy and mouldy aromas in the taste; faint sweetness underneath soft lemony and lactic acidity. Background flavours of wheatlike grains. Refreshing despite full chewy mouthfeel. Oily sensation, consistent with an aroma of walnut oil. I deliberatley chose and aged sample. Recent tries on draught revealed a sorry diminishing of the unbelievable complexity of this superb beer. This description is how it can, and ought to be.

Tap. Malty, hoppy, cheesy armoma. Hazy, yellow color, white head, nice lace. Start quite neutral but soon gets intens. Sweet to very sweet, maybe even too sweet. Fruity, honey, little cheesy, flavorfull and complex. Full and sticky. I think that this might be a here that could better be consumed from a bottle.

75cl Corked 2003 vintagePoured a cloudy golden orange color with a creamy white head. Aroma slightly sour and fruity. Some lemon, skunk and barnyard funk also present. Really wonderfully complex. Body is medium with a velvety smoothness and a lively carbonation. Flavor is spicy like a Tripel with some nice citrus in there as well. Good retention leaving scattered lacing in my Trappist glass. Overall one of the best in this style that I've had.
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: nice to have it on the tap, but not really someting to come back for, it's to my taste to lightly flavoured in nose and first taste, but the finish is much better, slowly the aroma's develop in your palate. It's a nice X-mas beer, but not the best.

Slightly hazy golden yellow with a thick, tight, white head.  A nice, complex aroma.  Some sweetness, orange peel, coriander, straw/hay, grass and a light floral perfume.  Not extremely funky in the nose; however, there were occasional bouts of funk that almost resembled a light skunkiness.  Sort of a light and airy mouthfeel with an effervescence that tickles the tongue.  The flavors are quite exquisite.  Lightly floral with pleasant citrus tendencies.  Things are well complimented by a nice spicy yeast character and a bitter hop finish.  Clean and dry with only a hint of sweetness (green apple and honey) from time to time.  A very pleasing Saison for a cold Chicago night.  Many things to frielock for sending me down memory lane and back to the warm summer (despite it being a holiday beer).
a good frothy lasting head, almost clear orange, sweet & malty flavor and tase
(Bottle)  Pours a cloudy yellow color with a beautiful frothy white head.  Has a good complexity of malt, citrus, and spice.  Very nice.

Hazy straw color like the label, thicker white head. Malt, citrus, and musty barnyard in the aroma. Flavor was malty up front with some citrus, funk, and quite a bit of hops at the end. Mouthfeel was lively, had a dry finish, excellent masking of the alcohol. Very good.

(bottled, Monk's). Straw color with voluminuous white head and brilliant clarity.  Malt & yeasty rustic aroma with amazing musty barnyard undertones.  Wonderful complexity with strong malt lead-off and firm bitter & very dry finish.  Substantial alcohol and big body.  A real winner.

Pours a golden blond with a strong fluffy white head. The nose is sweet and earthy. There is malt, candy sugar, musty basement and moldy rag in the nose. Absolutely wonderful taste! More malt, some barnyard notes, wheat and yeast, flowers, light spice and many more that I can't describe. Complex and bountiful taste. It finishes with a light bitterness and definite spice. Awesome beer!

Hay, tilled earth, mold, slight wet barnyard, and a touch of honeycomb.  Glowing yellow with a thick swath of foam.  Subtle bitterness with grassy sweet malts, earthy hops with a slight but thick bitterness.  Finnishes with lots of subtle fresh grain.  Great relaxing saison.

2002 750mL Bottle served at 10ºC in a saison flute. Upon opening, the cork exploded off the bottle with tremendous force almost putting a hole in my ceiling...impressive. Pours a crisp beige sand color with large white champagne like head, lacing sticky as a Hawaiian gecko's feet. Aroma is RICH with ripe citrus fruit and a terrific tart barny background, best saison aroma I've had yet, world class. Flavor is complex sour with barely a hint of alcohol, this is has wonderful leather flavors and sweet complexities. Hints of unfermented candi sugar are there too, so this would age to a 5 I believe. Fruity carbonated finish with a slight tart alcohol feel to keep the background full of surprises. The aroma in this one is what goes the distance for me; I would give it a 12 if I could, so the bonus points spill over into the overall category. Saison's are my favorite type of beer and are very unique and hard to find, I feel this is the best beer I've had up to date. Cheers!

Post Drinking Comments: I noticed that when the yeast was included at the end of the bottle, the flavor profile was dramatically affected and the citrus flavors were now dominated by a toasty chewy funkiness. I was meticulous with keeping this bottle stored properly and pouring slowly and I was well rewarded; keep this in mind if you ever have this one.

(750ml bottle):  Hazy golden with quickly dissipating off-white head.  Aroma is medium sweet, perfumy, orange peel, light floral, light coriander, yeasty.  Taste is flavorful, orange, spicy (coriander).  Finishes with moderately sweet alcohol light burn.warming.  Soft mouthfeel.  Very tripelesque.

Cloudy gold color.  Big head, but a loose one that dissipates quickly and leaves lacing on the glass.  We used Garrett Oliver's new book, "The Brewmaster's Table," to decide to have this with the grilled tuna and mango salsa we were having for dinner.  It paired wonderfully.  It has a slightly sour, yeasty aroma with some candy sugar in the background.  The flavor is very, very pleasant.  Sweet, slightly alcohol, light, but rich.  It does have quite a lot in common with a tripel, which happens to be my current favorite style.

UPDATED: MAR 31, 2006 January 31 2004 Hazy golden with big fluffy white head, bit of yeast and spice in the aroma and flavour. I couldnt pick out a ton of aroma out of it. Flavour is very subtle does not give any hint of the alcohol content it holds. Good beer but too unassertive for me. 6/3/6/3/15

August 2001 Belgian, I am assuming its a tripel (i was wrong). Strong, rather alcoholic taste. Somewhat interesting aroma. Decent but not especially great. 6/3/5/3/10

Dirty, hazy golden color with a thick white head that eventually diminishes. The aroma was filled with hay/grass at first and later became a zesty fruitiness with some mild yeast and hops tones. The flavor was a mixture of barnyard, citrus fruits, and hops. Lively, bubbly feel with a dry finish.

This strong saison style ale pours a cloudy golden color with a medium sized white head that recedes into a lingering film on top of the beer. The aroma is fruity and slightly tart with a mild yeastiness. It has a medium body with a moderate to high amount of carbonation. The flavor is slightly citrusy and mildly hoppy with a nice hoppy finish with hints of fruit and yeast. Very crisp and refreshing, the alcohol is well hidden. Very nice, it's like the Arnold Schwarzenegger version of their Saison Dupont Vieille Provision.
I guess I still have to acuire a taste for saisons, not a bad brew. Could not believe the the "life" that came out of the bottle when I opened it.
different.   Lightly musty, aroma of citrusy fruit.  Yellow in color with a thick creamy head.  very gritty and rough.  very dry.  absolutely no sign of the alcohol.
Great Saison.  I have had a few better, but this is a very close second.  Wonderful full-bodied taste with a slight bit more bitterness than usual.  Very nice and original.

Had from bottle on April 18, 2003 at the Suffed SandwichAn interesting beer, it pours with a small white head and a cloudy yellow coloring.  The flavor is initially acidic with a bitter finish.  I enjoyed the citric flavoring which masks the 9.5% ABV very well.

mild horse nose comes from the dark murky straw body which holds one hell of a huge white head on the pour i got.  bitter finish cleans up the tart start which yeilds to a grainy flavor and light alcohol notes.

Vintage 2001: firm frothy head. Hoppy, citric aroma and flavor. Pinetree. You really can't notice the alcohol. Long hopbitter citric finish. Medium bodied and a good lacing. A delicious high quality beer.
I described this one as "sunshine clear", don't ask. Has a decent head. Smells like rotten wheat.
Cloudy straw color. Medium head. Spicy aroma. Peppery. Yeasty. Hops in the finish. Light. Extremely drinkable. Oh yeah!!
A pale cloudy yellow body. Aromas was sour, citrus and florals. A flavor of citrus, bananas, yeast and wheats.
A murky yellow lake bottom color to it.  A minimal dusting of white head.  Smells like seasoned pork chops on the grill.  Tastes like yeasty bananas with a bitter bitter end to it.

This is a really tough one to read.  On the aroma I had that burst of what might be called "cheesiness" that others describe, but at the same time, I couldn't help but wondering...is this skunked?  I would have a hard time believing that.  Nice pour, big white head, creamy, reflected in the palate, which was excellent of creaminess and zestiness.  The flavor was better than the aroma, containing hints of spice, fruit, and yeast.  Good beer, but somewhat disconcerting.

Pours a bright and cloudy yellow in color, nice creamy frothy white lasting head. Flowery, grassy spicy and fruity aromas, fruity, yeasty spicy and slightly sour wheat flavors. Medium boby, smooth and silky mouthfeel with some bitterness, finishes, crisp and dry with alcohol in the aftertaste, great for the style.

Cloudy pale yellow out of the bottle with frothy white head and a sharp sour nose.  Lots of spicyness to this beer with coriander, clove and the flavor profile I associate with a belgian wit.  Clean and crisp and easy drinking for 9.5%.

Poured a cloudy yellow, with a good sized somewhat rocky white head, good yeasty aroma with hints of spice and hay. spicy flavor with hints of citrus. Tad on the sweet side and the Alcohol shows through a bit strong about half way through. My first and definately not last saison

UPDATED: NOV 21, 2016 2016 bottle. Head is initially large, frothy, white, mostly lasting. Body is
hazy dark yellow, bottle conditioned. Aroma is lightly to moderately malty (toasted grain), lightly hoppy (flowers, herbs), lightly yeasty (cobwebs), with light notes of pepper, alcohol, lemon zest, and gum. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly to moderately bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, moderately bitter. Medium body, velvety/watery texture, lively carbonation, moderately to heavily alcoholic.

Its been a long time since Ive had a 4+ bottle of Avec. Despite its breeding and being well-made, its just never that exciting or something I want to drink much of. And thats mostly for two reasons: the alcohol, and the relatively mild/quiet aroma. Its all the usual Dupont aromas, but theyre always quieter in this one than the other Dupont brews. Which allows the high alcohol to stick out more, both in the aroma and in the afterburn as well. I still feel a bit romantic about the beer, but the reality is that I never buy more than one per year and rarely drink much of the bottle. While the 2016 regular Dupont Saison was much better than usual, the Avec is about the same as always.

UPDATED: SEP 16, 2006 Aroma is spicy. Cloudy golden colour; remaining head. Spicy, bit sour taste. bitter finish.
[rerate] Aroma of citrus, yeast, hops with earthy tones. Cloudy, yellow coloured with a lasting white head. taste is bitter, a little tart and sweet, yeasty, citric some whine/grapes, eartyness. Quiet dry. Well balanced stuff. I like saison.

UPDATED: APR 26, 2016 Very cloudy golden color, impressive head. Cheesy aroma, bit yeasty. Very spicy, tripel-like flavor. Finishes a bit bitter and very dry with some alcohol shining through. Phenomenal beer, i like it more every time i drink it.

UPDATED: FEB 8, 2014 Rerate 2014: Tap @ DDDH, medium sample. Hazy golden color, medium white head. Aroma is a bit cheesy, bit grainy, some flowery and spicy hop, bit spicy. Bit creamy body, not as dry and crisp as the bottled version can be. Hint of sweetness. Nicely balanced, but seems to lack some complexity to make the score change.
Original rate 2007: Cloudy golden color, nice thick creamy head. Spicy aroma, bit sour, cheesy. Taste is spicy, triple-like. Bit dry palate.

UPDATED: APR 1, 2004 On tap at 'Den Dyver', Brugge. Blond, cloudy with a small head. Sweet, sour and mature aroma. The taste is hop fruit and citrus. Fairly carbonated. Bitter aftertaste. A very nice beer. Perfect with fish. First rated: 18 Dec 2002.

UPDATED: JAN 24, 2005 New -several samples of the 2004 - how can you tell? L04 on the label. The 2004 is different than this beer has been in several years, apparently. Its dry-hopped now, and it cuts the sweetness considerably. Like liquid flowers and herbs, flowing all over your sweet cottony saison. Lovely. Original: Highly spicy and also pretty sweet and also a lot of alcohol. Umm. Thats not bothering me tonight! Actually, I like the little bit of barnyard stink in the nose, the itty bitty wafts of candi sugar, but theres no weird herbal essence or minerality. It is a lot like a triple. Just enough funkiness to keep it real interesting. But Fantome Winter and de Pipaix are the real loves of my afeared Saison life.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: UPDATED: JAN 22, 2008 Bottle... This beer rocks... I tasted this beer at a non-RB party. Nothing kills a group buzz like a guy scribbling in a notebook. Rely on my score and the descriptions provided by other Ratebeerians.

UPDATED: DEC 23, 2009 75cL bottle, no dates.  Dead sexy pour, hazy goldenrod color, stark white foam with great retention and lacing.  Lacing isnt even a strong enough word, foam is hanging onto the side of the glass in clumps, like little bits of meringue.  Aroma is classic Dupont, green apple skins, black pepper, little bit of honey and some grassy and herbal hop notes.  Damn near perfect flavor, initially pils malt gives some sweetness, some rock candy sweetness.  Mid palate is some rock candy flavors, finishes with some green apple and strong bitterness.  9.5%abv, unbelievable, barely a note of the strength.

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2003 rigorous pours get rigorous results..cloudy yellow ones that is..with huge clouds..and fragrant citrus patches with wheaty weeds growing in unknown places..fizzy onslaught of spiciness..much more beligan triple spice than my experiences with saisons..which is a real letdown..I'm not a huge fan of the overly spiced..and this is overly spiced..so be it..not what i look forward to in a saison..

Sprigs of pine and peels of lemon form a subtle cloud of aroma.  The thin solid white head lasts and lasts, even as it thins, floating over a light yellow straw-gold lake that thins around the edges. I have to say, that this has quite a bit of originality in taste. It starts out a bit thin and lemony, then it sits on your lounge for a while and warms it up without any aftertaste, and for a final bow, it wows you with a spiced up, almost cinnamon like finish loaded with a good balanced dry bitter hop and alcohol finish, very complex in the end. Give this to someone who doesnt think any beer could stand up to a good champagne, itll blow them away.
Foamy, respectable head.  Sweet, bready aroma that contrasts with the more fruity taste.  Nicely balanced malt/hops.  Dry finish, not bad.
Not bad. Nice, frothy head, yeasty/spicy aroma, syruppy sweet finish.  Well masked ABV
I buy it when I can find it!  A very good, flavorful saison.  The alcohol is not noticable, so take care with this one!

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2007 Spicy perfume aroma. Big white head that lasted. Golden and cloudy. Distinct Saison flavor. Fruity and spicy, some graininess. Slightly bitter finish. Bubbly and smooth in my mouth. I finally found a little shop in this town that has some halfway decent beer selection so I picked this up. Very glad I did. I think Saison is one of my new favorite styles. Dont let its light girly appearance and aroma fool you, this stuff kicked my ass. Alcohol well hidden.
Spicy and robust, moderate Belgian yeast character, subdued alcohol presence
Poured a beautiful orange color with a fluffy white head. Nose of oranges and spice. Flavor is exceptional with the alcohol expertly hidden.
Had this a couple of years ago; liked it enough to give a few bottles as Xmas gifts. Dont recall much besides that. ;)

UPDATED: MAR 18, 2015 SuperSaison Intensity in the doughy yeast rusticity and spicy hopsImmensity for the cushiony cereals (barley and wheat?) and grassy bitternessBoozed up Vieille Provision Saison Dupont, yet wise and reverend...An irresistible Dulcinea under 10 degrees Celsius...
Sampled bottle was from 1998. Golden cloudy beer with stony aroma and lot of minerals and cellar tones. Spicy, sourish flavor. I don´t think I get this beertype I must admit.

UPDATED: NOV 24, 2003 Sampling of the 1998 version in 2002: Pale golden, very rich head, very lively. Blue cheese and citrus in the nose. Lively, light mouthfeel. Dry, funky and fruity. Dangerously drinkable with nice late bitterness.

Some variability, with tartness and hay and musk independently this way or that.  A spectacular presentation with an even silky foam and lace over a bright golden color. Uncorking brought out a wicked genie hydra part cow patty, part hay bale, part skunk.  The aroma subsides to yield some fruit vinegar, curacao and more hay and acetic acid. The bitter is solid yet yielding to the alcohol spice. This is a challenging and delightful ass kicker at 9.5%! 40oz and I split a 750 -- we should have split ravidesais magnum.
Spicy and refreshing. A little tart. I thought it was outstanding!!!!!
Not as good as Foret, but a solid tasty offering.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2009 Bottle. Hazy yellow. hazy yellow, huge white head. Peach, mango and citruspeel aroma, light tart. Dry mouthfeel, citrus, the fruits, yeasty funkiness, vanilla, herbs. Fairly fizzy on the onset, more pleasant if you beat some of the carbonation out. Wooden yeast dry aftertase, orangepeel retronasal.

Wit-ish in color; thin but lively head with great lace; Aroma is firm, but I cant put my finger on it. Dry right away. Very full mouthfell with a beautiful sharpness across the tongue. Alcohol is well represented. Has a lot of the yeasty characteristics of a witbeer. Small amount of spiciness reminds you that it is a saison. Another winner from Dupont.
Wonderful Belgian, sweet after taste.  and a well rounded hop bouquet.
Yeasty, citrusy, banana aroma.  Yeasty, fruity, spicy taste with a refreshing acidic sourness.  Great call user ex.

Duponts christmas saison brew.
outstanding stuff.  golden straw colour, slightly hazy which took on a green hue due to the christmas lights at my pub. clean foamy head. 
many different tastes - a complex beer. my notes include oranges, yeast, bananas, cloves, wheat grass.
unlike other beers , it maintains its tastes  and does not mellow after a few sips.
not a cheap or easy beer to finf but worth it . the magnum bottle may look like a lot to drink but this was a pleasure all the way.

While not the best Triple Ive had, this was a very nice beer.  It was beautiful in the glass, leaving an appropriate amount of yeast cloudiness.  Very well pronounced alcohol kick, though overall I felt that this beer was just slightly bland for the style.

UPDATED: JAN 27, 2004 cloudy bright orange colour with a big creamy head, estery and cider-like aroma with touches of vinegar, grapefruit and cork, sweet and full-bodied, acidic, dry alcohol and fruity finish (mostly apple) - powerfull and balanced
